title: Scott Walker Bets on Midwestern Appeal in Iowa
content:
BOONE , Iowa—Shortly after chopping up slabs of Iowa-bred pork ribs to distribute to Republicans at an event over the weekend , Wisconsin Gov . Scott Walker ticked through his Midwestern roots .
He told the crowd here that he lived in Plainfield , Iowa , then grew up in Delavan , across the state line in Wisconsin . His grandfather was a machinist in Rockford , Ill. And Mr. Walker noted that Harley-Davidsons , like the rented one that he rode to the event , are made in Milwaukee , just a few blocks from his home in Wauwatosa , Wis .
Mr. Walker ’ s bet on his regional appeal comes after a generation of Midwestern Republicans , including Michele Bachmann , Tim Pawlenty and Tommy Thompson , failed to catch fire campaigning in Iowa ’ s first-in-the-nation presidential contest . Regional appeal , in fact , hasn ’ t helped any Republican candidate win here since Bob Dole of Kansas carried the GOP caucuses two decades ago .
The Wisconsin governor , who is likely to formally enter the presidential campaign in July , is the only Republican who can tell Iowans he ’ s from the neighborhood , and he isn ’ t just playing to local self-regard . Central to his argument is that he can move Iowa and its neighbors into the win column for the Republican Party in 2016 .
While GOP rivals Marco Rubio , Rand Paul and Jeb Bush suggest they can make inroads in minority communities , Mr. Walker talks about winning Midwestern states like Wisconsin that Republicans haven ’ t carried since Ronald Reagan was on the ballot . He regularly trumpets the fact that he has won three statewide elections in Wisconsin , and he said at an Iowa fundraiser last month that the next Republican president would be elected through the Midwest .
“ When you look at Iowa , ” he said , “ you look at Wisconsin , you look at Michigan , you look at Ohio , sometimes you include Pennsylvania…you look at those key states , and I think that ’ s the pathway by which the next president is going to get elected . ”
Mr. Walker ’ s references to the Midwest know few bounds . His standard stump speech includes a long riff about Kohl ’ s , the Wisconsin-based department store . After he toured Israel last month , Mr. Walker told audiences that his helicopter tour of the country “ makes you realize that Israel is not much different in size from our states in the Midwest. ” Speaking last week in Florida at an economic conference , Mr. Walker ticked through 12 Florida cities he ’ d visited , including “ Naples , where there ’ s a lot of Midwesterners . ”
Jeff Kaufmann , chairman of the Iowa GOP , said Mr. Walker ’ s regional roots might not hand him victory in the caucuses , “ but it helps warm people up to listen to his message , and I think it will be helpful to his campaign . ”
Potential rivals from faraway places also have a steeper learning curve on Iowa issues . After Sen. Lindsey Graham ( R. , S.C. ) was approached here Saturday by a pair of agriculture activists seeking to get his position on ethanol subsidies , he replied , “ I don ’ t know much about soybeans , but I ’ m willing to learn . ”
Mr. Walker , who has placed first in almost every recent poll of Iowa Republicans , is the most formidable Midwestern GOP presidential hopeful since Mr. Dole , who won Iowa twice , in 1988 and 1996 . No one else has threatened victory , with few even competing .
Iowa Democrats , by contrast , have rewarded plenty of Midwesterners , with Walter Mondale of Minnesota ( 1984 ) , Dick Gephardt of Missouri ( 1988 ) , Tom Harkin of Iowa ( 1992 ) and Barack Obama of Illinois ( 2008 ) all winning the caucuses .
Mr. Pawlenty , who framed his 2012 presidential campaign around a Midwestern everyman persona , said proximity can be helpful to make a connection with voters .
“ Geography can be a proxy for familiarity to the tone and the feel of a place that ’ s similar to a place you come from , ” Mr. Pawlenty said . “ It ’ s another way of saying , ‘ I get you . I know you . I understand your concerns , and I can relate to people like you , because I ’ m like you . ’ ”
On a trip to Iowa for a state GOP fundraising dinner last month , Mr. Walker told how while growing up in Plainfield , Iowa , he raised money to purchase a state flag to fly above the town hall .
“ Stories like that are what ’ s great about Iowa , ” Mr. Walker said , as the crowd roared . “ It ’ s what ’ s great about the Midwest , what ’ s great about America. ” Later that evening , Mr. Walker , in a hospitality suite , donned an apron and doled out bratwursts , cheese and Miller Lite .
Said Jeff Ortiz , a co-chairman of the Republican Party in Story County , Iowa : “ That ’ s just the Midwest way of doing things . ”
content_original:
BOONE, Iowa—Shortly after chopping up slabs of Iowa-bred pork ribs to distribute to Republicans at an event over the weekend, Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker ticked through his Midwestern roots.

He told the crowd here that he lived in Plainfield, Iowa, then grew up in Delavan, across the state line in Wisconsin. His grandfather was a machinist in Rockford, Ill. And Mr. Walker noted that Harley-Davidsons, like the rented one that he rode to the event, are made in Milwaukee, just a few blocks from his home in Wauwatosa, Wis.

Mr. Walker’s bet on his regional appeal comes after a generation of Midwestern Republicans, including Michele Bachmann, Tim Pawlenty and Tommy Thompson, failed to catch fire campaigning in Iowa’s first-in-the-nation presidential contest. Regional appeal, in fact, hasn’t helped any Republican candidate win here since Bob Dole of Kansas carried the GOP caucuses two decades ago.

The Wisconsin governor, who is likely to formally enter the presidential campaign in July, is the only Republican who can tell Iowans he’s from the neighborhood, and he isn’t just playing to local self-regard. Central to his argument is that he can move Iowa and its neighbors into the win column for the Republican Party in 2016.

While GOP rivals Marco Rubio, Rand Paul and Jeb Bush suggest they can make inroads in minority communities, Mr. Walker talks about winning Midwestern states like Wisconsin that Republicans haven’t carried since Ronald Reagan was on the ballot. He regularly trumpets the fact that he has won three statewide elections in Wisconsin, and he said at an Iowa fundraiser last month that the next Republican president would be elected through the Midwest.

Presidential hopeful and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker rode a Harley-Davidson to a GOP Roast and Ride event Saturday in Boone, Iowa. Photo: Scott Olson/Getty Images

“When you look at Iowa,” he said, “you look at Wisconsin, you look at Michigan, you look at Ohio, sometimes you include Pennsylvania…you look at those key states, and I think that’s the pathway by which the next president is going to get elected.”

Mr. Walker’s references to the Midwest know few bounds. His standard stump speech includes a long riff about Kohl’s, the Wisconsin-based department store. After he toured Israel last month, Mr. Walker told audiences that his helicopter tour of the country “makes you realize that Israel is not much different in size from our states in the Midwest.” Speaking last week in Florida at an economic conference, Mr. Walker ticked through 12 Florida cities he’d visited, including “Naples, where there’s a lot of Midwesterners.”

Jeff Kaufmann, chairman of the Iowa GOP, said Mr. Walker’s regional roots might not hand him victory in the caucuses, “but it helps warm people up to listen to his message, and I think it will be helpful to his campaign.”

Potential rivals from faraway places also have a steeper learning curve on Iowa issues. After Sen. Lindsey Graham (R., S.C.) was approached here Saturday by a pair of agriculture activists seeking to get his position on ethanol subsidies, he replied, “I don’t know much about soybeans, but I’m willing to learn.”

Mr. Walker, who has placed first in almost every recent poll of Iowa Republicans, is the most formidable Midwestern GOP presidential hopeful since Mr. Dole, who won Iowa twice, in 1988 and 1996. No one else has threatened victory, with few even competing.

Iowa Democrats, by contrast, have rewarded plenty of Midwesterners, with Walter Mondale of Minnesota (1984), Dick Gephardt of Missouri (1988), Tom Harkin of Iowa (1992) and Barack Obama of Illinois (2008) all winning the caucuses.

Mr. Pawlenty, who framed his 2012 presidential campaign around a Midwestern everyman persona, said proximity can be helpful to make a connection with voters.

“Geography can be a proxy for familiarity to the tone and the feel of a place that’s similar to a place you come from,” Mr. Pawlenty said. “It’s another way of saying, ‘I get you. I know you. I understand your concerns, and I can relate to people like you, because I’m like you.’ ”

On a trip to Iowa for a state GOP fundraising dinner last month, Mr. Walker told how while growing up in Plainfield, Iowa, he raised money to purchase a state flag to fly above the town hall.

“Stories like that are what’s great about Iowa,” Mr. Walker said, as the crowd roared. “It’s what’s great about the Midwest, what’s great about America.” Later that evening, Mr. Walker, in a hospitality suite, donned an apron and doled out bratwursts, cheese and Miller Lite.

Said Jeff Ortiz, a co-chairman of the Republican Party in Story County, Iowa: “That’s just the Midwest way of doing things.”

Write to Reid J. Epstein at Reid.Epstein@wsj.com
